review.title: Fault-Tolerant, but Paradoxical Path-Finding in Physical and Conceptual Systems
review.abstract: We report our initial investigations into reliability and path-finding based models and propose future areas of interest. Inspired by broken sidewalks during on-campus construction projects, we develop two models for navigating this "unreliable network." These are based on a concept of "accumulating risk" backward from the destination, and both operate on directed acyclic graphs with a probability of failure associated with each edge. The first serves to introduce and has faults addressed by the second, more conservative model. Next, we show a paradox when these models are used to construct polynomials on conceptual networks, such as design processes and software development life cycles. When the risk of a network increases uniformly, the most reliable path changes from wider and longer to shorter and narrower. If we let professional inexperience--such as with entry level cooks and software developers--represent probability of edge failure, does this change in path imply that the novice should follow instructions with fewer "back-up" plans, yet those with alternative routes should be followed by the expert?

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: A few years ago, Western Kentucky University began a series of construction projects to replace Gary A. Randsdell Hall, the Augenstein Alumni Center, and the Downing Student Union. Part of the rebuilding process is the regular and temporary removal of sidewalk lengths across the campus, giving workers access to pipes like water, electricity, and so on under the concrete. To minimize disruption, these relocations are scheduled for the less busy summer and winter semesters, and it was during one such summer that I paid my rent by working on campus. Every morning, I cycled from my apartment near the southwest edge of campus to the northeast beach, where I worked as a web application developer for the Kentucky Mesonet.ar Xiv: 140 6.22 34v1 [cs.SE] 9 JQuickly, although I was frustrated walking around these broken sidewalks, finally asked, "What is the most reliable way on campus?"

sections.heading: 2 Review
sections.text: This problem has obvious and well-researched implications for computer and information networks, but it also has implications for design processes introduced in Section 5. We note here the research on related graph theory and fault tolerance problems and their differences with our problem. Thomas Wolle looks at an undirected graph with risk probabilities associated with each edge, and calculates for multiple errors "for a large number of different properties whether Y holds." [11] Akiyuki Yano and Tadashi Wadayama look at undirected acyclic graphs, where risk is associated with each edge, but these risks are functions of a hidden random variable [1]. Panagiotis Papadimitratos et al and Weidong Cui et al seek multiple paths through a network, so that the correlation of errors between graph paths is minimized.

sections.heading: 3 Definitions
sections.text: Our solution is based on the concept of "risk accumulation" backwards from the vertex of the target point. Once the vertex of the source is reached, the scout greedily selects the edge with the least accumulated risk at each step. If a failed edge is found, the scout updates his knowledge of the network, gathers anew, and continues it. To model this behavior, the scout's current knowledge of the network should be graph G = (V, J) with a series of probabilities of risk associated with edge group J. Let Ri define the risk of edge i and edge i its accumulated risk. Our principle theory then is to determine the correct definition of R so that a greedy scout behaves optimally.

sections.heading: 4 Validation
sections.text: If the combined risk of all the paths that pass through each edge is known, why should the Boy Scout not choose what minimizes that risk? Equation 3 determines this combined risk and can be divided into three terms: the first, Bi, represents the probability that I myself will fail; the second, Bj, the probability that all neighbors of i will fail; and the third, Bi (i; j) A (j), a sum of fragmented probabilities, each the chance that a given neighbor will be selected and the risk that remains after that edge.

sections.heading: 5 Implications
sections.text: We now turn our attention to the probable scenario in which R is unknown. Unless there is specific information about the distribution of lengths and risks in the network, we can only assume that all edges are equally long and the same risk is 0 ≤ α ≤ 1. If Ri is left as a variable in both models, this has an interesting result: a polynomial is associated with each edge [6]. For the sake of simplicity, it should be noted that P (α; i) denotes the polynomial for edge i if R = {α,...}. The consequence of these polynomials in development applications is a "risk aroxon," in which there is no universally safe path. That is, since the value of α is aligned from zero to one, the path that a greedy pathfinder would follow changes. In the example of Figure 2, it is more reliable to take the longer but denser path; however, above this value it is best to run on the shorter path because "the best examples are for it to be intuitive."

sections.heading: 5.1 Baking Cakes
sections.text: An accessible example of this paradox might be to follow the instructions for making a cake. Instead of linking risks to each edge, risks are linked to the experience of each cook. Therefore, an experienced cook would have a low α, while a beginner would have a high α. And instead of a simple recipe, there are alternative steps throughout the process that ultimately lead to the same cake. It may seem that the less experienced cook wants to take the conceptual path with more "back-up" plans, but in a scenario structured like Figure 2 with a success rate of one-third or less, these back-up plans are not enough to compensate for the increased number of steps.

sections.heading: 5.2 Software Engineering
sections.text: A hypothetical software company has developed a design process structured as a graph that has the "risk paradox." This company has contracts with customers who expect reliably delivered products, and the employees of that company have a wide range of experience levels. A developer intern has been assigned a particularly difficult individual project - perhaps as a skill test. What path through the development process should he or she take? Should this newcomer deal with the "most reliable shortest route" [5]? Should the start-up "just run around" until it has gathered the necessary experience to work as a team? How should the project manager take the skill level into account when planning the task sequence? Because this paradox - and this problem - has little applicability in processes that are simple or have minimal ramifications, perhaps we will benefit by including explorative phases in our considerations, such as the initial conversations with the customer, and how the requirements following the meeting may be fixed or unclear.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Herbert Simon proposed a curriculum for "design science," starting with the philosophical definition of the "artifact," and ending with a human model that defines all human activity as navigating through conceptual space. [10] From this point of view, where design is progressing by exploring possible next steps and implementing them in order and in search of a satisfactory end goal, our pathfinding problem is particularly powerful and forms the basis for a framework of "reliable design." Our research in this area is still in its infancy. It has been thoroughly researched in communication networks [3]. We then deal with physical systems very similar to our "broken sidewalk" - if not literally sidewalks - where their condition has deteriorated in cities to such an extent that "even if the sidewalks miraculously stopped, it would take 69 years to repair all existing damage." Secondly, we will consider two-way concepts, perhaps, in a process that we can consider and consider.
